channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Zoombombing countermeasures are ineffective in the vast majority of cases
item.description: Password-protecting meetings is among the most ineffective protections.

item.title: Google Pixel phones will soon track heart rate using only the camera
item.description: No PPG, no problem: Just stick your fingertip on top of the camera lens.

item.title: SpaceX Starlink passes 10,000 users and fights opposition to FCC funding
item.description: Electric co-ops say Starlink is “experimental” and shouldn’t get FCC money.

item.title: New report on Apple’s VR headset: 8K in each eye, potential $3,000 price tag
item.description: Plus, our analysis: How legit is this idea, anyway?

item.title: Today’s best tech deals: LG OLED TVs, Amazon Kindle Paperwhite, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on recommended laptops and noise-canceling headphones.

item.title: Parler CEO says board fired him for planning to ban “neo-Nazi” groups
item.description: Matze claims he wanted platform back online, but other leadership refused compromise.

item.title: Amazon will use cameras and AI to monitor delivery drivers
item.description: Footage of potentially dangerous situations will be uploaded to the cloud.

item.title: Ancient embalmers used mud to hold a damaged mummy together
item.description: After grave robbers damaged the remains, embalmers undertook emergency repairs.

item.title: White House says its supports Artemis Program to return to the Moon [Updated]
item.description: “We urge you to proceed with the planned selection.”

item.title: A silicon chip shortage is causing automakers to idle their factories
item.description: Automakers canceled orders due to COVID-19, and foundries switched to other customers.

item.title: Ford Mustang Mach-E review: The people’s pony goes electric
item.description: Not quite as much fun—or efficient—as a Tesla Model 3.

item.title: Rare 50 million-year-old fossilized bug flashes its penis for posterity
item.description: It dates back 50 million years, so this group may be twice as old as previously assumed.

item.title: SolarWinds patches vulnerabilities that could allow full system control
item.description: Fixes come as SolarWinds sorts out its role in a major hack on its customers.

item.title: Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine looks good in early analysis
item.description: If the results hold up—a big if—we’ll have another good vaccine option.

item.title: Pornhub brings in third-party “identity verification” system for users
item.description: Ideally, the arrangement would both confirm consent and keep performer data private.

item.title: Amazon begins delivering packages with prototype electric trucks
item.description: Amazon is aiming to put 100,000 Rivian electric trucks on the road by 2024.

item.title: AT&T customer since 1960 buys WSJ print ad to complain of slow speeds
item.description: Open letter to CEO asks why AT�T left DSL areas with shoddy Internet access.

item.title: Malicious Chrome and Edge add-ons had a novel way to hide on 3 million devices
item.description: 28 malicious extensions disguised traffic as Google Analytics data.

item.title: GSK eyes next-gen COVID vaccine as it inks deal to help boost current supply
item.description: GSK, Sanofi, Novartis step up to help boost global COVID-vaccine supply.

item.title: Modded Game Boy looks like an Apple product, works as Apple TV Remote
item.description: Yeah, it works as an Apple TV remote—but it’s also beautiful to behold.

item.title: Boston Dynamics’ robot dog gets an arm attachment, self-charging capabilities
item.description: The world’s most advanced commercial robot can now open doors and turn valves.

item.title: Sony says semiconductor shortage makes increased PS5 production difficult
item.description: Record-pace gaming profits face drag from loss-leading PS5’s “strategic price points.”

item.title: Microsoft backs Australian law forcing Google to pay for news links
item.description: Google has vowed to shutter Australian search engine before paying for news links.

item.title: Borderlands studio gets scooped up in deal worth up to $1.37 billion
item.description: Randy Pitchford will stay on atop Gearbox under Swedish conglomerate Embracer.

item.title: On eve of first launch, Firefly revamps board of directors, may go public
item.description: Out: Max Polyakov. In: Two senior US government officials.

item.title: Destruction AllStars review: Amazing PS5 car combat, in spite of speedbumps
item.description: The TL;DR of our first-day impressions: “This nearly launched as a $70 game?!”

item.title: We have finally played the lost, official Goldeneye 007 remaster for Xbox 360
item.description: It’s real, and it’s spectacular.

item.title: Putting the latest Starship crash into perspective—it’s “stupidly difficult”
item.description: “It’s not like they were huge idiots who wanted to throw their rocket away.”

item.title: New study cracks the case of why food sticks to center of nonstick pans
item.description: It’s the same underlying process behind the coffee ring effect and wine tears.

item.title: New COVID cases dropping, but worrying signs on the horizon
item.description: Easing off restrictions while cases are still common is asking for another surge.

item.title: B.1.1.7 coronavirus variant is picking up a worrisome new mutation
item.description: There’s a lot of unknowns, but it’s clear the virus isn’t done trying to outwit us.

item.title: EA is getting back into college football without NCAA, player licenses
item.description: Partnership with CLC means new title will feature rights to 100 individual schools.

item.title: Containerize all the things with Ubuntu Core 20
item.description: What if everything—and we mean everything—was a container?

item.title: Jeff Bezos to leave Amazon CEO post after 27 years, become executive chair
item.description: AWS executive Andy Jessy will replace Bezos as Amazon CEO in Q3 this year.

item.title: Google settles federal gender and race discrimination charges for $3.8M
item.description: About 5,500 workers will receive a few hundred dollars each from the deal.

item.title: Comcast lifts uploads to 5Mbps amid complaints its low-income plan is too slow
item.description: Speeds raised to 50Mbps down and 5Mbps up after complaints from students.

item.title: High-performance computers are under siege by a newly discovered backdoor
item.description: Stealthy Kobalos malware has infected HPC networks belonging to high-profile organizations.

item.title: Apple’s updated App Store guidelines clarify positions on recent controversies
item.description: Among the changes: game-streaming clarification, payment requirements, and more.

item.title: Tesla bows to pressure from NHTSA, issues recall for Models S and X
item.description: In late January, the automaker told NHTSA there was no defect; NHTSA disagreed.

item.title: SpaceX crashes a second Starship into South Texas [Updated]
item.description: It’s time to see if SN9 can stick the landing in South Texas.

item.title: Scalpers aren’t the main reason you can’t find a new console
item.description: …but they certainly aren’t helping.

item.title: Mass Effect Legendary Edition 4K remaster coming May 14
item.description: I’m Commander Shepard, and this is my favorite 4K upgrade on the Citadel.

item.title: Today’s best tech deals: AirPods Pro, Fitbit trackers, Lenovo ThinkPads, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on the MacBook Air, OLED TVs, and lots of video games.

item.title: Huawei’s HarmonyOS: “Fake it till you make it” meets OS development
item.description: No discernible difference between Huawei’s “all-new” OS and Android.

item.title: Flash is dead—but South Africa didn’t get the memo
item.description: Adobe: You can’t use Flash in 2021. South Africa: Watch me!

item.title: Hackers are exploiting a critical zero-day in devices from SonicWall
item.description: “Highly sophisticated threat actors” exploit flaws in coordinated attack on SonicWall.

item.title: Media frenzy, skepticism engulf virus origin probe—and WHO is over it
item.description: It’s “time for people who say and think they have information to start providing it.”

item.title: We’re getting a Wakanda spinoff series from Ryan Coogler on Disney+
item.description: It’s part of a 5-year exclusive TV development deal for the Black Panther director.

item.title: Apple rolls out macOS Big Sur 11.2 with bug fixes and Bluetooth tweaks
item.description: macOS update comes a week after updates to iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, and watchOS.

item.title: SpaceX announces first “free flyer” human spaceflight
item.description: “This is an important milestone towards enabling access to space for everyone.”

item.title: Why victims of AT&T unlimited-data throttling get only $22 in settlements
item.description: Victims of deceptive “unlimited” plans paid hundreds, get just a fraction back.

item.title: Why Animal Crossing: New Horizons’ 31 million sales are so incredible
item.description: In 9.5 months, New Horizons makes up almost half of all Animal Crossing sales.

item.title: 70% of top “civic” Facebook groups are toxic or violent, report finds
item.description: Internal report found top civic groups “non-recommendable” due to hate, harassment.

item.title: New supply chain attack uses poisoned updates to infect gamers’ computers
item.description: If you’ve used NoxPlayer in the past 5 months, it’s time to check for malware.

item.title: Google closes Stadia’s dedicated game studios after less than 2 years
item.description: Service isn’t changing, but path to streaming-exclusive games will clearly narrow.

item.title: Facebook makes the case for activity tracking to iOS 14 users in new pop-ups
item.description: In a new test, Facebook pre-empts Apple’s required prompt with its own.

item.title: Xiaomi denies ties to China’s military, calls US ruling “unconstitutional”
item.description: Xiaomi says DOD ruling last month “deprived the company of legal due process.”

item.title: Ford is switching to Android OS for infotainment in 2023
item.description: Ford and Google are also partnering to improve vehicle cloud services.

item.title: Dogs have been our best friends for at least 23,000 years
item.description: They accompanied the first people to set foot in the Americas.

item.title: It’s official—NASA will subject the SLS rocket to another hot fire test
item.description: “A second, longer hot fire test should be conducted and would pose minimal risk.”

item.title: Ars Technicast special edition, part 2: Open systems and the “joint force”
item.description: How the military is striving to make its technology a little more Lego-like.

item.title: As Virgin Galactic gets swept up in GameStop mania, it gets back to flying
item.description: Company says its next window for a test flight opens on February 12.

item.title: Goldeneye 007’s lost Xbox 360 remaster has leaked—as a full-game speedrun
item.description: Speedrunner talks to Ars, claims the remake is (mostly) on par with N64 original.

item.title: Hedge fund Melvin sustains 53% loss after Reddit onslaught
item.description: $4.5 billion drop in assets after bets against the likes of GameStop go sour.

item.title: Multi-layered Outside the Wire is part action thriller, part intimate drama
item.description: Director Mikael Håfström on making a military action movie that is ultimately anti-war.

item.title: An electric race car has lapped Daytona for the first time
item.description: We may well see an electric touring car series in the US in the next few years.

item.title: A curious observer’s guide to quantum mechanics, pt. 4: Looking at the stars
item.description: How do photons travel across light years? (Their quantum waviness enables modern telescopes.)

item.title: New study: A zero-emissions US is now pretty cheap
item.description: In 2050, benefits to the US offset costs, but there are some unexpected outcomes.

item.title: Why kids matter in the quest to stamp out COVID-19
item.description: Inoculating kids can help protect an entire population.
